block.p: A Domain Name Slips Away, And a Company Scrambles Panix.com, New York City's oldest commercial Internet service provider, saw its domain name slip out of its control over the weekend and become the center of an international hunt to get it back.

Whether maliciously or inadvertently, the company's main domain name, panix.com, was somehow transferred to a company in Australia. The incident served as a reminder that domain names are as vulnerable to theft as any other digital commodity. [Page C6.]

Apex Offers Details of Detention Apex Digital, in a court filing, offered a detailed account of how its president was detained by the Chinese police and, it says, coerced into signing agreements with its Chinese partner, Sichuan Changhong Electric. [C6.]

Nissan Chief May Run Renault, Too Carlos Ghosn, left, who turned around the fortunes of Nissan Motor, is expected to be named chief executive of Renault. He would be the first person in the auto industry to take on such dual roles. Mr. Ghosn's success at Nissan led it to leapfrog Honda to the No.2 spot in Japan in six years. The question is whether he can improve on that performance at Renault. [C12.]
Panel to Back Cuts in Medicare A federal advisory panel will recommend a cut in Medicare payments promised to hospitals and a freeze in payments to nursing homes and home care agencies. [A15.]
Yahoo to Develop Verizon Portal Verizon said it would work with Yahoo to build a Web portal for its high-speed Internet service. [C4.]
European Media Lab to Shut Down Media Lab Europe, a research institution set up by the Irish government and M.I.T., will close because it did not attract enough corporate sponsors. [C2.]
European and Asian Stocks Rise Stocks in European and Asian markets posted gains, while United States markets were closed. They will reopen today. [C10.]
Corporate Retreat, Moat Optional Europe's castles, palaces and manor houses are welcoming American companies and associations that rent them for meetings, gala dinners and other functions. [C14.]

Fare Changes Worry Frequent Fliers Some frequent business fliers say they are agitated about a possible drop in the number of first-class seats available for free upgrades. Joe Sharkey: On the Road. [C15.]

Diaper Makers Move Into Toiletries The makers of the two top diaper brands, Huggies and Pampers, are both introducing lines of toiletries for babies and small children. Next month, Huggies will begin selling a disposable bath mitt, liquid soap, shampoo and conditioner for toddlers. Advertising. [C8.]

A Domain Name Slips Away, And a Company Scrambles Panix.com, New York City's oldest commercial Internet service provider, saw its domain name slip out of its control over the weekend and become the center of an international hunt to get it back.

Whether maliciously or inadvertently, the company's main domain name, panix.com, was somehow transferred to a company in Australia. The incident served as a reminder that domain names are as vulnerable to theft as any other digital commodity. [Page C6.]
